name: Fort Bowie National Historic Site
description: For nearly 25 years, Fort Bowie stood at the crossroads of the Chiricahua Apache's fight to defend their ancestral homeland and the U.S. Army's westward expansion. Today, visitors embark on a 3-mile scenic loop trail traversing the ground where this profound cultural collision forever altered the course of both American and Indigenous history.
shortDescription: For nearly 25 years, Fort Bowie stood at the crossroads of the Chiricahua Apache's fight to defend their ancestral homeland and the U.S. Army's westward expansion. Today, visitors embark on a 3-mile s...

operatingHours.description: The Historic Site trails and ruins are open every day from sunrise to sunset. Please see Visitor Center tab for museum and visitor center hours.

images.title: Fort Bowie Ruins
images.altText: Ruins of the fort with mountains and valley in the background.
images.caption: San Simon Valley can be seen just beyond the ruins of the cavalry barracks.

images.title: Mountain howitzer
images.altText: Close up of a canon barrel
images.caption: The mountain howitzer is a symbolic relic from the active days of Fort Bowie

images.title: Post Trader's Store
images.altText: Ruins of adobe building under a blue sky with white clouds.
images.caption: The Post Trader's store on a spring day.

images.title: Fort Bowie landscape and ruins
images.altText: Ruined walls of the old buildings and mountains in the background
images.caption: Fort Bowie was once a bustling frontier military fort. Today, the ruins offer a place of reflection.

images.title: Fort Bowie Cemetery
images.altText: Black and white photo of white tombstones in a cemetery, mountains in the background
images.caption: Fort Bowie cemetery is accessed via the Fort Bowie Trail, and in addition to many US troops buried here, some Apache/Indeh are buried here as well.

images.title: Heliograph demonstration
images.altText: A group gathers as a ranger displays the heliograph equipment
images.caption: The heliograph was an important communications tool in the late 1880s. Stationed on top of high desert peaks, sunlight was reflected off mirrors in coded patterns to send a message miles away.
